1605114 / 1605071
PIs: Bond, Jesse Q. / Crossley, Steven P.
Title: Collaborative Research: SusChEM: Phase-specific catalysis combined with reactive distillation for the selective production of butadiene from y-valerolactone

Economically feasible conversion of biomass to chemicals is of critical importance for sustainability. Inherent inefficiencies in alkane activation and production gaps caused by the recent shale gas boom have created niches within the petrochemical industry that might realistically be filled by biomass. The goal of this collaborative project is to develop a new technology for selective production of a relatively high-value petrochemical, butadiene, from aqueous solutions of gamma-valerolactone, a biomass derived chemical. The butadiene markets have become increasingly volatile after the recent paradigm shift in refinery operation. The researchers will develop a multiphase reactor to achieve selective butadiene production from aqueous solutions of gamma-valerolactone.

The envisioned chemical transformation occurs through sequential ring opening of valerolactone to form pentenoic acid isomers, which subsequently undergo decarbonylation to form butadiene. A multiphase reactor will be employed to achieve ring opening of valerolactone to form pentenoic acids in an aqueous phase, extraction of these pentenoic acids into an organic phase, decarbonylation of pentenoic acids in the organic phase to form butadiene, and reactive distillation of butadiene from the organic phase to a sweep gas. Fundamental studies of the governing phenomena will be undertaken in order to develop strategies for maximizing butadiene selectivity. The aim will be to integrate non-ideal solution thermodynamics, phase and chemical equilibria, reaction kinetics, and transport phenomena into an overall process model and functional reactor design. This approach will also lead to a better fundamental understanding of condensed phase catalysis and multiphase reactors. In addition to training graduate students, the PIs plan to engage high school and undergraduate students in their research and develop an educational module on biomass refining.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Olefins and diolefins such as butadiene are critical components for the production of synthetic rubbers and a variety of other chemicals that we use each day. Until recently, these chemicals were produced as a byproduct of the crude oil conversion process. The emergence of cheap and abundant shale gas and shale oils has shifted this landscape. This has created a demand for specific chemicals such as butadiene, and a stronger incentive to make them in a more sustainable manner from renewable sources. This project focuses on tailoring chemistry for the production of these chemicals from lignocellulosic biomass, specifically by the conversion of C5 acids. It has recently been discovered that light C5 and C6 acids can be produced in an efficient manner from non-food biomass such as corn stover and wood. The challenge lies in developing a catalytic process that can selectively convert these species to these high value chemicals.

The goal of this project was to use a combination of unique catalyst design and reaction engineering to selectively convert these renewable acids to high value chemicals. This is not an easy task, as conversion of the acid is generally more difficult than other less desirable reactions that should be avoided. During the course of the project, two significant discoveries were made to help achieve this goal, the first was that the co-injection of other renewable alcohols can drastically improve rates of product formation. These alcohols were found to react with the carboxylic acids and make them easier to selectively convert in the liquid phase. This dramatically increases yields to the desired products. The second major discovery was regarding a new class of catalyst that had not been explored in detail for this carboxylic acid chemistry. It was found that specific reducible oxides can exhibit remarkable selectivity for this reaction by creating defects on their surface that are subsequently healed by the acids to generate the products of interest while leaving other parts of the molecule untouched. This allows for the production of the desired products at high rate while avoiding side reactions. These results are promising for the production of butadiene and pentadiene, but could open up promising avenues for the production of chemicals from a wide range of other acids as well, ranging from those generated from biomass waste pyrolysis products to vegetable oils.

This project has provided training for 3 PhD students and 2 MS students at the University of Oklahoma and Syracuse University. Students involved have participated in several annual hands on summer camps aimed at encouraging first generation and minority students to pursue engineering. Examples and hands on activities focused on renewable energy. Students also interacted along with the PI in collaboration with the University of Oklahoma’s American Indian Science and Engineering Society chapter to carry out hands on activities and encourage K-12 students to pursue these important disciplines through various outreach events.
